contentList.content: A workbench that has seen better days. Used to upgrade ranged weapons, quarterstaffs, and clubs, as well as create new gear.

Grants access to work in the forge and on workbenches.
Makes it easier to savingthrows when upgrading weapons.
Gives proficiency with hammers.

Grants access to work in the forge and on workbenches.
Makes it easier to savingthrows when upgrading weapons.
Gives proficiency with hammers.
The value of Strength, Constitution or Dexterity increases by 1, to a maximum of 20.
It can be used to simplify the improvement of weapons, as well as the ingredient in some blacksmithing drawings.
The viscous dark green liquid slowly shimmers in the bottle.
No one on the team at [1] has oil in their inventory.
There are no slashing or piercing weapons in the main hand.
There are no ranged or wooden weapons in the main hand.
Applies a [1] attack penalty and a [2] damage penalty to the weapon.
Gives the weapon a bonus to attack [1] and damage [2].
Gives the weapon a bonus to attack [1] and damage [2].
Gives the weapon a bonus to attack [1] and damage [2].
This weapon has been enhanced by a skilled guild master, granting it a bonus [1] to <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">attack rolls</LSTag>.
Weapons are being upgraded, you need to wait until it is completed.
The action cannot be performed at this time.
Experience gained in the Artisan's Guild allows you to feel more confident in upgrading your equipment by adding <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> to checks.
Applies a [1] attack penalty and a [2] damage penalty to the weapon.
Applies a [1] attack penalty and a [2] damage penalty to the weapon.
The weapon in the main hand is too damaged to be repaired.

Weapon proficiency allows you to work on improving your weapon with greater confidence: it gives you a bonus [1] on skill checks and allows you to improve the weapon to a higher level if you pass an additional Sleight of Hand check.
An old, worn chest that is perfect for storing various tools and crafting materials.
Automatically collects matching items that enter your inventory.

Gains access to weapon upgrades at forges and workbenches, but the upgrade level is limited to a minimum.
Creating new equipment is only available to the blacksmith and, to a limited extent, to the artisan or elven races.

You have gained access to weapon upgrades at forges and workbenches, but the upgrade level is limited to a minimum.
Creating new equipment is only available to the blacksmith and, to a limited extent, to the artisan or elven races.
The pages of this book are covered in large, sloppy handwriting.
Elixir of Peerless Focus allows you to focus on your work and adds <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> to crafting checks.
This sturdy wooden workbench is covered in stains and nicks.
While the furnace is burning, weapons can be upgraded or forged on the anvil, depending on the strength of the fire.
The furnace is blazing with a hot fire, and the forge, if the anvil is intact, is ready for work.

The character has no knowledge of working with an anvil.
A blacksmith or his apprentice, as well as a member of the Artisan Guild, can have such knowledge.

The character has no knowledge of working with a workbench.
Such knowledge may be possessed by a blacksmith or his apprentice, a representative of the elven race, as well as a member of the Artisan Guild.
There is no fire in the smelting furnace
To work in the forge, you need to light the smelting furnace.
Hot fire is needed for forging, but normal fire is enough for upgrading.
Allows you to create new items based on the studied blueprints.
This drawing has not been studied.

Trap Disarm Toolkit
A necessary thing, to make it you will need to add tongs and shears to the thief's tools, and the rest is already there (Workbench).
These notes are a must-have for any adventurer interested in crafting.

A Blacksmith's Apprentice's Notes

Some apprentice's sloppy notes on the basics of using an anvil and workbench, as well as handling light hammers.
It's worth trying to improve a weapon.

Improving a Weapon
To improve a weapon, equip it in your main hand and use a tool.
If none of your allies have oil and you don't mind ruining the weapon, use the tool twice, ignoring the warning.

Anvil - Upgrades impact weapons (Blacksmith, Blacksmith's Apprentice, Guild Member).
Whetstone - Upgrades piercing and slashing weapons (no restrictions).
Workbench - Upgrades ranged and wooden weapons (Blacksmith, Blacksmith's Apprentice, Guild Member, Elven).

* Upgrades at an anvil are only available near a smelter with a regular fire burning.
* Oil is not required, but recommended. Without it, weapons can only be improved to a minimum level and with a high skill check.
* The difficulty of checks and the level of improvement are affected by the use of oil, the presence of the Blacksmith or Guild background trait, the player's level, weapon skills, etc.
* Representatives of the elven races can only improve ranged weapons on the workbench.
Constant contact with fire and oil has given the surface of the tongs a copper hue.
Constant contact with fire and oil has given the surface of the tongs a copper hue.
Constant contact with fire and oil has given the surface of the tongs a copper hue.
Constant contact with fire and oil has given the surface of the tongs a copper hue.
Constant contact with fire and oil has given the surface of the tongs a copper hue.
The blades have become dull from years of use.
After many years of use, the blades became dull.
This broom is completely worn out.
This blueprint has not been studied.

Bow
Simply take a wooden branch, weave a string out of rope, and you have a simple bow (Workbench).

Blacksmith's Notebook
For keeping notes on weapon making and on blueprints found during travels.

Elven Roots
Your Elven heritage allows you to use workbenches to create, rework and upgrade ranged weapons more easily and better than others.

Artison Past
Experience gained in the Artison Past allows you to use the workbench to improve weapons, create and rework equipment, while checks are easier to pass, and the equipment is of higher quality than others.

Blacksmith's Apprentice
You didn't learn much from the blacksmith's apprentice's notes, but you can now upgrade weapons at the workbench and anvil, at least to a minimum level. You can also create equipment on the workbench using blueprints that do not have special requirements.

Blacksmith
You have reached certain heights in weaponry and can improve weapons to a level inaccessible to others, as well as forge or rework equipment in the Forge. And with every second new level - your skill will grow!

No Crafting Skills
No crafting skills prevents you from using workbenches and forges, or sharpening weapons on whetstones above the minimum level. But this book will contain new blueprints and information about available crafting...
Save the book for later, perhaps you or someone on your team will receive such skills in the future.

Once the blueprint is read, the creation of the corresponding item will become available to any party member with the appropriate skills.
Information about the blueprint is also recorded in the Blacksmith's Notebook.

Once the blueprint is read, the creation of the corresponding item will become available to any party member with the appropriate skills.
Information about the blueprint is also recorded in the Blacksmith's Notebook.
You have studied the blueprint and recorded the necessary information in the Blacksmith's Notebook.
Forging is only available to characters with the Blacksmith feat.
Regular fire is suitable for improvement, but forging requires hot fire.
The ingredients seem to fit together, but you don't know the blueprint for combining them.
Requirements for creation are not met. Check what is written in the blueprint.

Blacksmith's Book

You have chosen the honorable path of the weaponsmith, which will allow you to provide yourself and your team with the finest weapons and armor that can be crafted. You also gain proficiency with light and warhammers.

Weapon Improvement
To improve a weapon, equip it in your main hand and use a tool.
If none of your allies have oil and you are not afraid of ruining the weapon, use the tool twice, ignoring the warning.

Anvil - Improves impact weapons (blacksmith, blacksmith's apprentice, Artisan Guild member).
Whetstone - Upgrade piercing and slashing weapons (no restrictions).
Workbench - Upgrade ranged and wooden weapons (Blacksmith, Blacksmith's Apprentice, Artisan Guild Member, Elven).

* Upgrade at the anvil is only available next to a smelter with a regular fire burning.
* Oil is not required, but recommended. Without it, weapons can only be improved to a minimum level and with a high skill check.
* The difficulty of checks and the level of improvement are affected by the use of oil, the presence of the Blacksmith trait or guild background, the player's level, weapon skills, etc.
* Representatives of the elven races can only improve ranged weapons on the workbench.

Creating Equipment
To create equipment, you need to find and read the blueprint, which will be stored in the Blacksmith's Notebook (can be found in forges).
After that, you can use the blacksmith spell to enter the creation mode, selecting the required number of slots, and use the anvil (blacksmith only) or workbench (blacksmith, blacksmith's apprentice, Guild member, representative of the elven race).

* Forging on an anvil is only available near a smelter in which a hot fire is burning.
* The blueprints also indicate the requirements for the tool on which it can be used, skills or abilities, and other requirements.

Reworking equipment
Reworking equipment is available to a blacksmith, a representative of the elven races (only ranged weapons), and a guild member (workbench).
Reworking is done using the Rework Chest. Place a template item, ingredients in it, and use a suitable tool nearby: a workbench or an anvil, depending on the template.
Usually, the workbench is used to rework light armor, ranged, wooden, and piercing weapons, while the anvil is used to craft medium and heavy armor, slashing, and impact weapons.
The book is written in the confident handwriting of a master who knows his own worth.
Elven Roots allows you to upgrade ranged weapons with greater confidence.
This weapon has been upgraded by a member of the Elven race, giving it a [1] bonus to <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">attack rolls</LSTag>.
Equipment created in the Sussur Forge gains additional properties.
This armor was created by a skilled guild master, giving it a bonus to <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">AC</LSTag> [1].
This weapon was created in a Sussur forge, giving it the anti-magic properties of Sussur.
This armor was created in a Sussur forge, giving it the anti-magic properties of Sussur.
If you hit an enemy, there is a chance that <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="SILENCED">silence</LSTag> will be applied to him.
An essential ingredient in any set.

Sussur Forge
After creating a weapon masterpiece, you have learned the secret of sussur forging, and as long as the sussur fire burns in the smelter, anti-magic properties are added to the created equipment. One sussur heat can create up to 3 items, but if you have additional sussur bark, it can be re-ignited.
This mode allows you to repair/rework weapons and armor, including broken or rusty ones.
Something went wrong while reworking the item. Verify that the template item and ingredients are in the chest, and that the selected character is capable of reworking such an item.
There is no known template item in the rework chest.
A character of the Elven race, but not a Blacksmith or Guild Artisan member, can only create or rework ranged weapons.
Check the rework chest for ingredients.
Check the rework chest for the template item and ingredients.
Allows you to create new items based on the studied blueprints.
This mode allows you to repair/rework weapons and armor, including broken or rusty ones.
After studying the drawing, select the creation mode and use an anvil or workbench, depending on the instructions in the blueprint.
Place the template and ingredients in the rework chest and use the anvil or workbench depending on the template.

To sharpen a weapon, equip it in your main hand and use the whetstone.
If no one on your team has oil, use the whetstone twice, ignoring the warning, but the sharpening check will be harder without oil.
This whetstone looks old and worn, but it still seems to be good for sharpening cutting and stabbing weapons.

To upgrade a weapon, equip it in your main hand and use the anvil.
If none of your allies have oil and you don't mind ruining the weapon, use the anvil twice, ignoring the warning.

To forge new gear, enter the desired creation mode and use the anvil.
A heavy and reliable anvil, all covered in traces of heavy blows of the blacksmith. If there is a working furnace nearby, then this anvil can still be used to improve or forge new equipment.

To upgrade a weapon, equip it in your main hand and use the anvil.
If none of your allies have oil and you don't mind ruining the weapon, use the anvil twice, ignoring the warning.

To forge new gear, enter the desired creation mode and use the anvil.
A heavy and reliable anvil, all covered in traces of heavy blows of the blacksmith. If there is a working furnace nearby, then this anvil can still be used to improve or forge new equipment.

To upgrade a weapon, equip it in your main hand and use the workbench.
If none of your allies have oil and you don't mind ruining the weapon, use the workbench twice, ignoring the warning.

To create new equipment, enter the desired creation mode and use the workbench.

Rework chest is used as a support tool when reworking equipment.

Use:
Place the template item, ingredients, and use a nearby tool: a workbench or anvil, depending on the template.
Typically, the workbench is used to rework light armor, ranged weapons, wooden weapons, and piercing weapons, while the anvil is used to rework medium and heavy armor, slashing weapons, and bludgeoning weapons.
To store information about characters' crafting abilities, as well as found blueprints and recipes.
Can be used as an ingredient in some blacksmithing blueprints.

Rework chest is used as a support tool when reworking equipment.

Use:
Place the template item, ingredients, and use a nearby tool: a workbench or anvil, depending on the template.
Typically, the workbench is used to rework light armor, ranged weapons, wooden weapons, and piercing weapons, while the anvil is used to rework medium and heavy armor, slashing weapons, and bludgeoning weapons.

Typically, the workbench is used to rework light armor, ranged weapons, wooden weapons, and piercing weapons, while the anvil is used to rework medium and heavy armor, slashing weapons, and bludgeoning weapons.

Use:
Place the template item, ingredients, and use a nearby tool: a workbench or anvil, depending on the template.

Typically, the workbench is used to rework light armor, ranged weapons, wooden weapons, and piercing weapons, while the anvil is used to rework medium and heavy armor, slashing weapons, and bludgeoning weapons.

Use:

Typically, the workbench is used to rework light armor, ranged weapons, wooden weapons, and piercing weapons, while the anvil is used to rework medium and heavy armor, slashing weapons, and bludgeoning weapons.
The shield is spattered with blood on both sides.
This shield is completely covered with dents and nicks, but on its surface one can still discern a half-erased image of a flower.
On the shield is the coat of arms of a long-forgotten noble house.
The surface of this sturdy shield is polished to a mirror finish.
The surface of the shield is covered with small spots of rust.
Black resinous drops slowly flow through the cracks.
The dark glass of the bottle both hides and protects the liquid inside.
An unknown liquid had dried at the bottom of the bottle.
Equipment created in the Gnome Forge gains additional properties.
This armor was created in the Gnome Forge, giving it <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">resistance</LSTag> to Force damage and increasing its <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">AC</LSTag> by [1].
This weapon was created in the Gnome Forge, which gave it Force properties: it ignores resistance to Force damage and deals additional [1].

Allows you to mark an item as blacksmith loot to automatically add it to the blacksmith's chest.
Can mark another container to collect in the standard item chest.
Equipment created in the Cursed Shadows Forge gains additional properties.
This armor was created in the Last Light Forge, giving it <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">resistance</LSTag> to necrotic damage and increasing its <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">AC</LSTag> by [1].
This armor was created in the Cursed Shadows Forge, giving it <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">resistance</LSTag> to radiant damage and increasing its <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">AC</LSTag> by [1].
This weapon was created in the Last Light Forge, giving it radiant properties: it ignores radiant damage resistance and deals additional [1].
This weapon was created in the Cursed Shadows Forge, which gave it necrotic properties: it ignores necrotic damage resistance and deals additional [1].
This weapon was created in the Forge of the Nine, which gave it fiery properties: it ignores fire resistance and deals additional [1].
This armor was created in the Forge of the Nine, giving it <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">resistance</LSTag> to fire damage and increasing its <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">AC</LSTag> by [1].
You can smelt metals in this crucible if you know how (Blacksmith).
On the shield is the coat of arms of a long-forgotten noble house.

To upgrade a weapon, equip it in your main hand and use the workbench.
If none of your allies have oil and you don't mind ruining the weapon, use the workbench twice, ignoring the warning.

To create new equipment, enter the desired crafting mode and use the workbench.
A workbench that has seen better days. Used to upgrade ranged weapons, quarterstaffs, and clubs, as well as create new gear.
A heavy and reliable anvil, all covered in traces of heavy blows of the blacksmith. If there is a working furnace nearby, then this anvil can still be used to improve or forge new equipment.

To upgrade a weapon, equip it in your main hand and use the anvil.
If none of your allies have oil and you don't mind ruining the weapon, use the anvil twice, ignoring the warning.

To forge new gear, enter the desired crafting mode and use the anvil.
Can be poured into suitable bottles.
Equipment created in the Last Light Forge gains additional properties.
Equipment created in the Forge of the Nine gains additional properties.
There are no ranged weapons in the main hand.
There is no impact weapon in the main hand.
This weapon was created by a skilled guild master, giving it a bonus [1] to <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">attack rolls</LSTag>.
This armor was created by a skilled guild master, giving it a bonus to <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">AC</LSTag> [1].
This weapon was created by a member of the elven race, giving it a bonus [1] to <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">attack rolls</LSTag>.
The wooden planks of the chest are burnt for strength and reinforced with thick strips of iron.
The wooden planks of the chest are burnt for strength and reinforced with thick strips of iron.
The wooden planks of the chest are burnt for strength and reinforced with thick strips of iron.
The wooden planks of the chest are burnt for strength and reinforced with thick strips of iron.
The wooden planks of the chest are burnt for strength and reinforced with thick strips of iron.
The wooden planks of the chest are burnt for strength and reinforced with thick strips of iron.

Forge Aura
In some forges, the equipment created gains additional properties. It's as if the forge adopts the atmosphere around it or the habits of the blacksmith working in it...

The weaponsmith can use hides to craft equipment at forges.
At a tanning rack, hides can be processed into leather and leather strips.

The weaponsmith can use hides to craft equipment at forges.
At a tanning rack, hides can be processed into leather strips.

Used to craft equipment in forges.
You can get it by processing the hide on a tanning rack.

Used to craft equipment in forges.
Can be obtained by breaking wooden objects.
A length of strong, hand-braided rope.

To tan a hide, you need the hide itself, oil, and a charcoal.
The amount of tanned leather and strips depends on the size of the hide.

Reworking
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Workbench (weapon):
Shortbow - branch
Longbow - two branches
Club, Pike, Spear, Trident, Warpick - branch and bronze
Halberd - branch and 2 bronzes
Quarterstaff, Glaive - branch, bronze and leather strip
Hand crossbow, Light crossbow - wood, bronze and rope
Heavy crossbow - wood, 2 bronzes and rope
Great club - wood, bronze and leather strip
Dart - bronze and feather
Workbench (armour):
Padded - leather and leather strip
Leather - 2 leathers and leather strip
Studded Leather, Ring Mail - bronze, leather and leather strip
Hide - wolf hide, 2 leathers and leather strip
Scale Mail - bronze, 2 leathers and leather strip
Workbench (shields):
Round shields - 3 woods, bronze and leather strip
Large shields - 4 woods, 2 bronzes and leather strip
Anvil (weapon):
Dagger - bronze
Battleaxe, Flail - wood, bronze and leather strip
Greataxe, Warhammer - branch, 2 bronzes and leather strip
Greatsword - 3 bronzes and leather strip
Handaxe - wood and bronze
Light hammer A, Mace, Morningstar - branch and bronze
Light hammer B, Maul - branch and 2 bronzes
Longsword - 2 bronzes and leather strip
Rapier, Scimitar, Shortsword, Sickle - bronze and leather strip
Anvil (armour):
Breastplate, Chain Shirt, Half Plate - 2 bronzes, leather and leather strip
Chain Mail, Splint, Plate - 3 bronzes, leather and leather strip

Rework chest is used as a support tool when reworking equipment.

Rework is available to blacksmiths, members of the Artisan Guild, or the Elven race from level 4.
You can only rework leveled items (normal, +1, +2), as well as their corrupted versions.
The result of rework depends on the character's level (normal item - level 4, +1 item - level 6, +2 item - level 8).

Use:
Enter rework mode, place the template item, ingredients, and use a nearby tool: a workbench or anvil, depending on the template.
The wooden planks of the chest are burnt for strength and reinforced with thick strips of iron.
